title: What are the practical ways of categorizing human knowledge? - Quora

response.answer_text: A. By generality and historical import. (Note: this benefits by toggling heavy vocabulary on / off and toggling personal preferences on / off).By relevance to current popular / current technical (This could be implemented by merely toggling between popular and technical, and toggling preferences off / on).B.→Alt criteria User input. (For example, consumer data, profiles, other data, previous search terms).Associations. (For example terms related to search [clicking] not obviously related to preferences).C. → Coherently. (Coherent tools can find what is considered the best broad-strokes advice or description). These systems are free to use with citation of Nathan Coppedge visible in the software / product / manual: Programmable HeuristicsIncoherently. (Incoherent tools are good at generating detailed models and customizations, and may depend on coherent models for structure without revealing this to the user).D. → Scientific classification / Taxa / Independent scholarly systems. (The labor of science is to provide detailed organizations that can be used to develop incoherent data, or the combination of coherent and incoherent data).Individual entry. (Specific specialists or organizations may provide enjoyable and also seperate fast-learning formats for phenomenally grasping various subjects, like abstracts, labels, or book descriptions, which may be suited to various personalities. You are free to use my extensive Quora content in original or modified form, such as my Coherent Systems project or history of philosopjy writings, or the section on brain uploads-downloads / early written stim culture).Also look up library catalog systems: Library classification - Wikipedia

The English philosopher Ryle famously distinguished between knowledge-how and knowledge-that… Knowledge How (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy) And people typically add a third kind: knowing in the sense of knowing someone personally. But I would use the Nate System. This categorises knowledge into four discrete and comprehensive types as follows: Things everyone knows - even people who foolishly disagree with me and don't think they are true, because these people are clearly in denial.Things only people of sufficient awareness - that is, me and people who agree with me - know.False knowledge - that is, anything which I don't think.Irrelevant knowledge - that is, facts I cannot deny, but which I refuse to let alter the more important fact that I am right anyway.I think that is all the types of knowledge. And since I don't think there are any others, any others that people think exist are false knowledge.
